titleStmt.title: The Famous History of Sir Thomas Wyatt 1602
titleStmt.author: Dekker, Thomas; Webster, John

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: Probably derived from the two parts of the lost play "Lady Jane", by Dekker, Thomas Heywood, John Webster, Henry Chettle, and Wentworth Smith.
The first word of the title is xylographic.
Running title reads: The famous historie of Sir Thomas Wyat.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: The famous history of sir Thomas Wyatt.
With the coronation of Queen Mary, and the coming in of King Philip.
As it was played by the Queen's majesty's servants.
Written by Thomas Dickers, and John Webster.
Printed by F. A. for Thomas archer, and are to be sold at his shop in the Popes-head palace, near the royal exchange.

div.head: The famous history of sir Thomas Wyatt

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: How fares the King, my lord?
Speaks he cherely?

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Even as a dying man, whose life
Like to quick lighting, which is
No sooner seen, but is extinct.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: Is the Kings will confirmed?

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Ay, that's the point that we level at.
But o, the confirmation of that will, 'tis all, 'tis all.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: That will confirm my daughter Queen.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Right, and my son is married to your daughter.
My lord, in an even plain way, I will
Derive the crown unto your daughter's head.
What though the King hath left behind,
Two sisters, lawful and immediate heirs,
To succeed him in his throne lies it not
In our powers to contradict it?
Have we not the King and counsel's hands unto it?
Tut, we stand high in man's opinion,
And the world's broad eye.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Here comes sir Thomas Wyatt.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Sir Thomas booted and spurred, whether away so fast?

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: It boots me not to stay,
When in this land rebellion bears such sway.
God's will, a court! 'tis changed
Since noble Henry's days.
You have set your hands unto a will.
'A will you well may call it:
So wills Northumberland:
So wills great Suffolk,
Against god's will, to wrong those princely maids.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Will you not subscribe your hand with other of the lords?
Not with me, that in my hands,
Surprise the sovereignty?

sp.speaker: Wyat.
sp.l: I'll damned my soul for no man, no for no man,
Who at doom's day must answer for my sin:
Not you, nor you my lords,
Who named Queen Jane in noble Henry's days,
Which of you all durst once displace his issue?
My lords, my lords, you whet your knives so sharp,
To carve your meat,
That they will cut your fingers.
The strength is weakness that you build upon,
The King is sick, God mend him, ay, God mend him:
But were his soul from his pale body free,
Adieu my lords, the court no court for me.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Farewell, I fear thee not.
The fly is angry, but he wants a sting,
And all the counsel: only this perverse
And peevish lord, hath only denied his hand
To the investing of your princely daughter.
He's idle, and wants power.
Our ocean shall these petty brooks devour,
here comes his highness' doctor.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: How fares his highness?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: His body is past help.
We have left our practice to the divines,
That they may cure his soul

sp.speaker: Aru:
sp.l: Past physics help, why then past hope of life,
Here comes his highness' preacher:
Life reverent man.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Life, life, though death his body do dissever,
Our King lives with the King of heaven for ever.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Dead! send for heralds, call me pursuivants,
Where's the King at arms? in every market town
Proclaim Queen Jane.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Best to take the opinion of the counsel.

sp.speaker: Nort.
sp.l: You are too timorous. We in ourselves
Are power sufficient: the King being dead.
This hand shall place the crown
On Queen Jane's head.
Trumpets and drums, with your notes resound,
Her royal name, that must in state be crowned. Exeunt om

sp.speaker: Guil:
sp.p: Our cousin King is dead.

sp.speaker: Ian:
sp.l: Alas, how small an urn contains a King?
He that ruled all, even with his princely breath,
Is forced to stoop now to the stroke of death.
Herded you not the proclamation?

sp.speaker: Gui:
sp.l: I hear of it, and I give credit to it
What great men fear to be,
Their fears grow greater.
Our fathers grow ambitious
And would force us sail in mighty tempests,
And are not lords of what they do possess.
Are not thy thoughts as great?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I have no thoughts so rank, so grown to head,
As are our father's pride.
Troth I do enjoy a kingdom having thee.
And so my pain be prosperous in that,
What care I though a sheepcote be my palace
Or fairest roof of honour.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: See how thy blood keeps course with mine:
Thou must be a Queen, ay me! A Queen,
The flattering bells that shrilly sound
At the King's funeral with hollow hearts,
Will cowardly call thee sovereign:
For indeed thou wouldst prove but an usurper.

sp.speaker: Ian,
sp.l: Who would wear fetters though they were all of gold?
Or to be sick, though his faint brows
For a wearing nightcap, wore a crown.
Thou must assume, a title that goes on many feet,
But 'tis an office, wherein the hearts of scholars,
And of soldiers will depend upon thy hearse.
Were this rightly scanned,
We scarce should find a King in any land.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Honour and happy reign
Attend the new majesty of England.

sp.speaker: Ian:
sp.p: To whom my lord bends this your have.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: To your grace dread sovereign,
You are by the Kings will, and the consent
Of all the lords, chosen for our Queen.

sp.speaker: Ian:
sp.l: O God! methinks you sing my death,
In parts of music's loudness,
'Tis not my turn to rise.

div.stage: Enter Northumberland, Suffolk with the purse and the mace, with others.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: The voice of the whole land-speakes in my tongue
It is concluded your majesty must ride,
From hence unto the tower: there to stay
Until your coronation.

sp.speaker: Ian:
sp.p: O God!

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Why sighs your majesty?

sp.speaker: Ian:
sp.l: My lord and father, I pray tell me,
Was your father's father ere a King?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Never, and it like your grace.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Would I might still continue of his line,
Not travel in the clouds.
It is often seen, the heated blood
That covets to be royal, leaves off ere it be noble,
My learned careful King, what must we go?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: We must.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Then it must be so.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Set forward then.
sp.stage: A dead march, and pass round the stage, and Guilford speaks.
sp.l: The tower will be a place of ample state,
Some lodgings in it, will like dead men's skulls,
Remember us of frailty.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: We are led with pomp to prison,
Oh prophetic soul.
Lo we ascend into our chairs of state,
Like funeral coffins, in some funeral
Pomp descending to their graves. But we must on.
How can we fare well, to keep our court:
Where prisoners keep their cave?

div.stage: Enter Queen Mary with a prayer book in her hand, like a nun.

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.l: Thus like a nun, not like a Princess born,
Descended from the royal Henry's loins:
Live I environed in a house of stone,
My brother Edward lives in pomp and state,
I in a mansion here all ruinate.
Their rich attire, delicious banqueting:
Their several pleasures: all their pride and honour,
I have forsaken for a rich prayer book.
The golden mines of wealthy India,
Is all as dross compared to thy sweetness.
Thou art the joy, and comfort of the poor,
The everlasting bliss in thee we find.
This little volume enclosed in this hand,
Is richer than the empire of this land.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Pardon me madam, that so boldly
I press into your chamber. I salute your
Highness with the high style of Queen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Queen! may it be?
Or jest you at my lowering misery.

sp.speaker: Ben:
sp.l: Your brother King is dead,
And you the Catholic Queen must now succeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see my God, at length hath heard my prayer.
You sir Harry, for your glad tidings,
Shall be held in honour and due regard.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.p: Health to the lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And why not Queen, sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: Ask that of Suffolk Duke, and great Northumberland
Who in your steed hath crowned another.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: Another Queen, sir Thomas we alive,
The true immediate heirs of our dread father?

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: Nothing more true than that:
Nothing more true than you are the true heir,
Come leave this cloister and be seen abroad,
Your very sight will stir the people's heats,
And make them cheerly, for Queen Mary's cry.
One comfort I can tell you: the tenants of the Dukes
Northumberland and Suffolk denied their aid,
In these unlawful arms: to all the counsel
I denied my hand, and for King Henry's issue still will stand.

sp.speaker: Mary:
sp.l: Your counsel, good sir Thomas, is so pithy
That I am won so like it.

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: Come let us straight from hence,
From Framingham:
Cheer your spirits.
I'll to the Dukes at Cambridge, and discharge them all:
Prosper me God in these affairs,
I loved the father well, I loved the son,
And for the daughter I through death will run. Exeunt omnes.
sp.stage: Enter Northumberland, Suffolk, Bret and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Where's captain Bret?

sp.speaker: Bre:
sp.p: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: Are all our numbers full?

sp.speaker: Bre:
sp.p: They are my lord.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: See them arraigned, I will set forward straight.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Honourable friends, and native peers,
That have chosen me to be the leader of these martial
Troops, to march against the sister
Of our late dead sovereign.
Bear witness of my much unwillingness,
In furthering these attempts,
I rather joy to think upon our ancient victories
Against the French and Spaniard,
Whose high pride we levelled with the waves of British shore
Dying the haven of Brit, with guilty blood,
Till all the harbour seemed a sanguine pool:
Or we desire these arms, we are now to war
'Gainst the perfidious Northern enemy,
Who trembling at our first shock voice and sight,
Like cowards turned their backs with sameful flight
But those rich spoils are past: we are now to go,
Being native friends, against a native foe.
In your hands we leave the Queen elected,
She hath seizure of the tower,
if you be confident, as you have sworn
Yourselves true liege men to her highness
She no doubt, with royal favour will remunerate
The least of your 〈◊〉. Farewell
My tears into your bosoms fall,
With one 〈◊〉 I do include you all.

sp.speaker: Aru:
sp.l: My lord most loved with what a mourning heart
I take your farewell, let the after signs
Of my employment witness. I protest.
Did not the sacred person of my Queen,
Whose weal I tender as my soul's chief bliss,
Urge my abode, I would not think it shame
To trail a pike where you were general.
But wishes are in vain, I am bound to stay,
And urgent business calls your grace away.
See, on my knees I humbly take my leave,
And steep my words with tears.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Kind Arundel, I bind thee to my love.
Once more farewell.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Heavens give your grace success.
Commend us to the Queen and to your son,
Within one week, I hope war will be done.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Come my lords, shall us march.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Ay, ay, for god's sake on.
'Tis more than time my friends, that we were gone. Exeunt omnes. 〈 ◊〉. 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.l: What ho porter! open the gate.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: I beseech your honour to pardon me,
The counsel hath given 〈◊〉 command
Not 〈◊〉 shall 〈◊〉 this way.

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.p: Why you idle fellow, am I not sent upon the Queen's affairs, commanded by the lords? and know you not that I am treasurer? come open the gate, 〈◊〉 do you know not what.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: Well my lord, I do adventure on your word.
The Duke's displeasure: all the counsel board
Bésides, may be my heavy enemies,
But go a god's name, I the worst will prove,
And if I die, I die for him I love.

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.p: I thank thee, and will warrant thee from death. Is my horse ready?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: It is my lord

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.p: Then will I fly this fearful counsel board,Exit Tre.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: My heart misgives me, I have done amiss,
Yet being a counsellor one of the number
Nothing can prove amiss.
Now shall I know the worst.
Here comes my lord of Arundel.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: Porter, did the lord treasurer pass this way?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: But now my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: Ungracious villain, follow,
Bring him back again,
sp.p: If not, by fair means bring him back by force:

And hear you sirrah, as you go, will the lord maior and some aldermen of his brethren, and some especial citizens of note, to attend our further pleasures presently. 〈◊〉 treasurer fled: the Duke is but newly arrested, some purpose, on my life, to cross their plots: we'll set strong watches, see gates and walls well manned: 'tis ten to one but princely innocence,
Is these strange 〈◊〉 wisest violence.
sp.stage: Enter Winchester, Arundell, and other lords: the lord treasurer 〈◊〉 at the counsel table.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: Though 'Your attempt, lord treasurer be such,
That hath no colour in these troublous times,
But an apparent purpose of revolt,
from the deceased Kings will, and our degree,
Yet, for you are a counsellor of note,
One of our number, and of high degree,
Before we any way presume to judge,
We give you leave to speak in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.l: My lord, the business of these troublous times,
Binding us all, still to respect the good of common weal:
Yet doth it not debar private regard of us and of our own
The general weal is treasured in your breast,
And all my ablest powers have been employed
To stir them there, yet have I born a part,
Laying the commons troubles next my heart,
My oversight in parting without leave:
Was no contempt, but only for an hour.
To order home affairs, that none of mine,
In these nice times should unto faction climb.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Nay my good lord, be plain with us, I pray,
Are you not grieved that we have given consent
To lady Jane's election?

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.l: My lords I am not,

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Speak like a gentleman, upon your word
Are you not discontent?

sp.speaker: Treasurer
sp.l: Troth to be plain, I am not pleased,
That two such princely maids lineally descended,
From our royal King, and by his testimony,
Confirmed heir, if that their brother dying issueless,
And one that never dreamt, it never desired
The rule of sovereignty,
But with virgin's tears hath oft bewailed her misery,
Should politicly by us be named a Queen.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.p: You have said nobly, sit and take your place.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: My lords, sir Thomas Wyatt craves access unto your honours.

sp.speaker: Arun
sp.p: Let him come near.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Room for sir Thomas Wyatt.

sp.speaker: W●at..
sp.l: A divine spirit teach your honour's truth,
Open your eyes of judgement to behold
The true legitimate, Mary your undoubted sovereign.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: A rise sir Thomas, sit and take your place.
Now to our former business:
The obligation wherein we all stood bound
To the deceased late Kings will and our decree,
His cousin Jane, and the two absent Dukes
Cannot be concealed without great reproach
To us and to our issue.
We have sworn in presence of the sacred host of heaven
Unto our late young lord, to both the Dukes,
That no impeachment should divert our hearts
From the impeachment of the lady Jane.
To this end we have ceased her in the tower,
By public proclamation made her Queen:
To this end we have armed the Duke, with power
Given them commission under our own hands
To pass against the lady. You perform in hostile manner
And no doubt, the spleen of the undaunted spirit
Of Northumber's Earl, will not be called
With writings of repeal.
Advice in this, I hold it better far
To keep the course we run then seeking change,
Hazard our lives, our heirs and the realms.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: In action's roving from the bent of truth,
We have no precedent thus to persist
But the bare name of worldly policy.
If others have ground from justice, and the law,
As well divine as politic agreeing,
They are for no cause to be disinherited.
If you not seven years since to that effect,
Swore to the father to maintain his seed,
What dispensation hath acquitted you
from your first sacred vows?
You'll say, the will extorted from a child.
O! let mine eyes in naming that sweet youth,
Observe their part,
Pouring down tears, sent from my swelling heart.
God, mother, I term child? but I'll go on,
Say that the will were his, forced by no trick,
But for religions love his simple act,
Yet note how much you err.
You were sworn before to a man's will,
And not a will alone,
But strengthened by an act of parliament.
Besides this sacred proof. The princely maids,
Had they no will nor act to prove their right?
Have birthrights no privilege, being a plea so strong,
As cannot be refelled, but by plain wrong?
Now were you touched. The lady in tower,
Alas she's innocent of my claim.
Trust me, she'd thinks it a most happy life,
To leave a Queen's, and keep a lady's name.
And for the Dukes, your warrants sent them forth,
Let the same warrant call them back again.
If they refuse to come, the realm, not they
Must be regarded. Be strong and bold:
We are the people's factors. Save our sons
From killing one another, be afraid,
To tempt both heaven and earth, so I have said.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: Why then give order that she shall be Queen,
Send for the mayor, her errors we'll forget,
Hoping she will forgive.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: Never make doubt, setting her ceremonious order by.
She is pure within, and mildly chaste without.

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: Give order to keep fast the lady Jane,
Dissolve the the counsel. Let us leave the tower, and in the city hold our audience.

sp.speaker: W●at
sp.l: You have advised well honourable lords,
so will the citizens be wholly ours,
And if the Dukes be cross, we'll cross their powers.

sp.speaker: Bre:
sp.p: Lance persado, quarter, quarter,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What shall we quarter captain?

sp.speaker: Bre:
sp.p: Why the soldiers?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why they are not hanged nor drawn yet?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Sir I mean quarter them, that the offended multitude, may pass in safety.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: May we not take tools of the pies and the aple-women

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Not in any sort the Duke's pleasure will pass free.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: The commons shall be used with all common courtesy
That goes in rank like beans and cheesecakes on their
Heads in stead of caps.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Sire, this is a famous university, and those scholars, those lofty buildings and goodly houses,
Founded by noble patrons. But no more. Set
A strong watch. That be your 〈◊〉 care.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 Souldiers●?

sp.speaker: B●e.
sp.l: Fear not, good speech, those rude arms I bear,
Is't not to fight, sweet, gentle peace away,
But to succour your lives, pass peaceably away.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Cry 〈◊〉 save the Queen as you go, and God send you a good market.

sp.l: God save the Queen, what Queen? there lies the se●se
When we have none, it can be no offence.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What carry you there in your basket? Mat. Eggs forsooth.

sp.speaker: C●o.
sp.l: Well, cry God save Queen Jane as you go, and
God send you a good market.

sp.speaker: Ma●..
sp.l: Is the right Queen called Jane? alack for woe,
At the first she was not christened so.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Thus old and young still descant on her name,
Nor lend no ear, when we horstile proclaim.
I fear, I fear. Fear Bret, what shouldst thou fear?
Thou hast a breast composed of adamant.
Fall what ill betide, my anchor is cast,
And I in harbour ride.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.p: My lord 'tis true, you sent unto the counsel for fresh supplies, what succour, what supplies? Happy is he can draw his neck out of the collar, and make his peace with Mary.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: How stands the treasurer addicted to us?

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: I had forgotten: when we wear at counsel,
He stole away, and went home to his house,
And by much entreaty was won to return,
In brief they all incline to Queen Mary
My lord farewell, each hasty hour:
Will colder tidings cell.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Come they in thunder, we will meet with them?
In the loudest language that their ordinance speaks,
Ours shall answer theirs.
Call me a herald, and in the market place proclaim
Queen jane. The streets are full,
The town is populous, the people gape for novelty.
Trumpets speak to them,
That they may answer with an echoning cry,
God save Queen Jane, God save her majesty.

div.stage: A trumpet sounds, and no answer. The herald sounds a parley, and none answers.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Ha? A bare report of trumpets!
Are the slave's horse, or want they art to speak?
O me! This town councils on famous colleges,
Such as know both how, and what, and when to speak,
Well, yet we will proceed,
And smother what close envy hath decreed.
Ambrose my son, what news?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: O my thrice honoured father,

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Boy, speak the worst,
That which sounds deadly est, let me hear that first.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: The lords have all revolted from your faction

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: We in ourselves are strong.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: In Baynard's castle was a counsel held,
Whether the mayor and sheriffs did resort,
And 'twas concluded to proclaim Queen Mary.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.p: Then they revolt the allegiance from my daughter, and give it to another:

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: True my thrice honoured father,
Besides, my brother Guilford and his wife
Where she was proclaimed Queen, are now
Close prisoners, namely in the tower.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: God take them to his mercy, they had need,
Of grace and patience, for they both must bleed,
Poor innocent souls, they both from guilt are free.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: O my thrice honoured father! might I advise
You, fly to your manner, there study for your safety.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Boy, thou sayest well,
And since the lords have all revolted from me,
Myself will now revolt against myself.
Call me a herald to fill their empty ears,
Assist me son, my good lord Huntington,
Even in this market town proclaim Queen Mary.

div.stage: A trumpet sounds a parley, the herald proclaims.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Mary by the grace of God, Queen of England,
France and Ireland, defendress of the faith. Amen.

div.stage: Within a shout and a flourish.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: Amen, I bear a part,
I with my tongue, I do not with my heart,
Now they can 〈◊〉, now they can bawl and yell,
Base minded slaves, sink may your souls to hell.

sp.p: My honoured lord, the counsel greets you with these letters.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Stay master Roose, ere you depart receive an answer and reward.
sp.l: In the sovereign name of Mary our Queen
You ●al upon the sight hereof,
Surcease your arms, discharge your soldiers,
And presently repair unto the court,
Or else to be held as an arch-traitor.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: 'Tis short and sharp, master Roose, we do obey your
Warrant: but I pray tell me, how doth all our friends at
Court? is there not a great mortality amongst them?
Is there not a number of them dead of late since I came thence?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My gracious lord not any.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: O master Roose, it cannot be, I will assure you
At my departure thence, I left living there at least
Five hundred friends, and now I have not one,
Simply not one: friends! ha, ha, ha, commission
Thou must be my friend.
And stand betwixt me and the stroke of death,
Were thy date out, my life's date were but short,
They are cold friends, that kills their friends in sport

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Here comes your honoured friend the Earl of Arundel.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: My 〈◊〉 friend!

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.l: I am no friend to traitors: in my most high and
Princely sovereign's name,
I do arrest your honour of high treason.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: A traitor Arundel? have I not your hand in my
Commission? let me peruse it: as I 〈◊〉 'tis here,
And by your warrant have so strict proceeded.
Is the limits of my warrant broke answer me.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: It may be that it hath pleased her majesty
To pardon us, and for to punish you.
I know no other reason, this I must,
I am commounded, and the act is just.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: And I obey you: when we parted last
My lord of Arundel, our farewell was
〈◊〉 then our greeting now.
Then you cried God speed,
Now you come on me ere you say take heed:
Than you did owe me your best bloods: nay greened
You could not spend them in my service.
O then it was a double death to stay behind,
But I am overtook and you are kind,
I am, beshrew you else, but I submit,
My crime is great, and I must answer it.

sp.speaker: Arun
sp.l: You must with your three sons, be guarded safe
Unto the tower: with you, those lords and knights
That in this faction did associate you,
For so I am enjoined.
Then peacively, let 〈◊〉 conduct you thither,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: O my children! my soul weeps endless tears for you.
O at the general sessions, when all souls
Stand at the bar of justice,
And hold up their new immortalised hands,
Oh then lot the 〈◊〉 of their tragic ends
Be raced out of the bead-roll of my sins:
When ere the black book of my crime's unclasped.
Let not these scarlet letters be found there:
Of all the rest, only that page be clear.
But come to my arraignment, then to death,
The Queen and you have long aimed at this head,
If to my children, she sweet grace extend,
My soul hath peace, and I embrace my end. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Three days are past, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday too
Yet my protesting servant is not come.
Himself conducted me to this hard lodging,
A simple cabin, for so great a prince,
And then he swore, but oaths you see are vain,
That he would hourly come and visit me:
I that was wont, to sur 〈◊〉 in estate,
Am now through hunger almost desolate.

div.stage: Enter Homes sweating with bottle and Bag.

sp.speaker: Hoom.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: Ned Homes, speak hast thou brought me meat?

sp.speaker: Hom:
sp.l: With much ado my lord, meat, bread and wine,
While you refresh yourself, I will record
The cause of my long stay.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: I prithee do, need bids me eat,
Need bids me hear thee too.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: The night I left you in the hollow tree,
My house was searched.

sp.speaker: Suff,
sp.p: Go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Hom:
sp.l: And I no sooner entered but attached,
Threatened the rack: and if I did not yield
Your gracious self into their graceless hands.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: And thou hast don't, thou hast betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: Done it! O betray you? O no!
First would I see my loved wife and children
Murdered, and tossed on spears, before I would
Deliver your grace unto their hands,
For they intend your death.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: Go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Hom:
sp.l: And offered a thousand crowns to him that can
Bring news of your abode, 'twas offered in my hands.
Which I beseech may stop my vital breath,
When I am fee'd with gold to work your death.

sp.speaker: Shoer:
sp.p: See yonder sits the Duke.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.p: I kiss thee in requital of this love.

sp.speaker: Hom:
sp.l: And in requital of so great a grace,
I kiss your hand that dares to kiss my face.

sp.speaker: She:
sp.p: So Judas kissed his master: cease the Duke.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: Ah me! Ned Homes we are undone,
Both thou and I betrayed.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.p: My lord, late Duke of Suffolk, in her highness' name I do arrest you of high treason.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: I do obey, and only crave this kindness,
You would be good unto my servant Homes,
Where in relieving me, hath but performed
The duty of a servant to his lord.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: You are deceived sir in your servant much,
He is the man that did betray you.
Here master Homes, towards your thousand pounds,
Here is a hundred marks,
Come to the exchequer, you shall have the rest.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: Hast thou betrayed me? yet with such a tongue,
So smoothly oiled, slight of my dangers fear,
Oh break my heart, this grief's too great to bear.

sp.speaker: Ho:
sp.p: Pardon me my lord.

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: God pardon thee, and lay not to thy soul
This grievous sin: farewell.
And when thou spendest this ill got gold
Remember how thy master life was sold.
Thy lord that gave thee lordships, made thee great,
Yet thou betrayd'st him as he sat at meat.
On to my grave, 'tis time that I were dead,
When he that held my heart betrays my head.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: O God, oh God, that ever I was born,
This deed hath made me (Slave) to abject scorn.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O poor shrimp, how art thou fallen away for want of munching? O Colen cries out most tyrannically, the little gut hath no mercy, what's here victuals? O rare! O good! Feed chops, drink throat, good victuals makes good blood.
sp.stage: Enter Homes with a halter about his neck.
sp.l: But stay, whose here? more sheriffs more searchers?
O no, this is Homes that betrayed his honest master,
how, with a halter about his neck? I hope he doth
Not mean to hang himself? I'll step aside .

sp.speaker: H●.
sp.l: This is the place, where I betrayed my lord,
This is the place where oft I have relieved:
And villain I, betrayed him to the jaws of death,
But here before I further will proceed
Here will I bury this enticing gold,
Lie there damned fiend never serve human more,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is rare, now in this mood he would hang himself 'twere excellent.

sp.speaker: Ho:
sp.l: Shall I ask mercy? no it is too late,
Heaven will not hear, and I am desperate.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: So, so, a very good ending, would all false servants
Might drink of the same sauce.
Gold, you are first mine, you must help
To shift myself into some counterfeit suit
Of apparel, and then to London:
If my old master be hanged, why so:
If not, why rustic and lustick:
Yet before I go, I do not care if I throw this dog in
A ditch: come away dissembler: this cannot choose but be
A hundred pound it ways so heavy.

div.stage: Enter Queen Mary, Winchester, Norfolk, Pembroke, Wiat, Arundell, attendants.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: By god's assistance, and the power of heaven,
After our troubles we are safely set,
In our inheritance, for which we do subscribe
The praise and benefit to God, next thanks
To you my lords. Now shall the sanctuary,
And the house of the most high be newly built.
The ancient honours due unto the church,
buried within the ruin monasteries,
Shall lift their stately heads, and rise again
To astonish the destroyers wand'ring eyes.
Zeal shall be decked in gold,
Religion not like a virgin robbed of all her ponipe,
But briefly shining in her gems of state,
Like a fair bride be offered to the lord.
To build large houses pull no churches down,
Rather in rich the temple with our crown.
Better a poor Queen, than the subjects poor.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: May it please your grace to give release
Unto such ancient Bishops that have lost their
Honours in the church affairs.

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: We have given order to the Duke of Norfolk to release them.

sp.speaker: Aru:
sp.l: Your sacred highness will no doubt be mind
Full of the late oath you took at 〈◊〉 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O my lord of Arundel, we remember that,
But shall a subject force his prince to swear
Contrary to her conscience and the law?
We here release unto our faithful people,
One 〈◊〉 subsidy,
Due unto the crown in our dead brother's days.
The commonalty shall not be 〈◊〉 burdened
In our reign, let them be libre all in religion,
And we will spare their treasure to themselves:
Better a poor prince than the nation poor,
The subjects' treasure, in the sovereign's store.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.p: What is your highness' pleasure about the rebels?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The queenlike rebels,
Mean you not Queen Jane?

sp.speaker: Arun:
sp.p: Guilford and Jane, with great Northumberland, and haughty Suffolk's Duke.

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.l: The Duke of Suffolk is not yet apprehended,
Therefore my lords,
some of you most dear to us in love,
Be careful of that charge:
The rest we'll leave for try all of the other prisoners.

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: The lady Jane most mighty sovereign,
Allied to you in blood: for she's the
Daughter of your father's sister.
Mary the Queen of France: Charles Brandon's
Wife your niece, your next of blood, except your sister,
Deserves some pity, so doth youthful Guilford.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Such pity as the law allows to traitors.

sp.speaker: Norf.
sp.p: They were misled by their ambitious fathers,

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: What son to obey his father proves a traitor,
Must buy their disobedience with their death.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.p: My lord of Winchester, still thirsts for 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wyatt no more, the law shall be their judge,
Mercy too mean offenders we'll ostend,
Not unto such that dares usurp our crown.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Count Edmond the ambassador from Spain,
Attends your highness' answer, brought those
Letters sent from the emperor
In his son's behalf.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: In the behalf of lovely princely Philip,
Whose person we have shrined in our heart?
At the first sight of his delightful picture
That picture should have power to tingle
Love in royal breasts: the darts of love are words, pictures,
Conceit, he'll prevail by any,
Your counsel lords about this foreign business.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: I say and it like your royal majesty,
A royal treaty, and to be confirmed,
And I allow the match.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Allow it lords, we have cause
To thank our god, that such a mighty prince
As Philip is, son to the emperor,
Heir to wealthy Spain, and many spacious
Kingdoms, will vouchsafe —

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.p: Vouchsafe! my lord of Winchester, pray what?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: To grace our mighty sovereign with his honourable title.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.p: To marry with our Queen: mean you not so?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I do, what then?

sp.speaker: Wia●.
sp.l: O God! is she a beggar, a forsaken maid,
That she hath need of grace from foreign princes?
By god's dear mother, oh God pardon swear I,
Methinks she is a fair and lovely prince,
Her only beauty (Were she of mean birth)
Able to make the greatest 〈◊〉,
I the great emperor of the 〈◊〉 cham,
That hath more 〈◊〉 under his command,
Then Spanish Philip's like to inherit towns,
To come and lay his scepter at her feet,
And to entreat her to vouchsafe the grace
To take him and his kingdom to her mercy.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: W●at you are too hot.

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.l: And you to proud vouchsafe? O base!
I hope she'll not vouchsafe to take the emperor's
Son to her dear mercy.

sp.speaker: Ma●
sp.p: 〈◊〉 my lord of Winchester I pray.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Then 〈◊〉 I say, we have cause to thank our god,
That such a mighty prince will look so low,
As to respect this island and our Queen.

sp.speaker: Vvia:
sp.p: Pardon me madam, he respect your 〈◊〉 more than your person? think of that.

sp.l: Wyatt, you wrong the affection of the prince,
For he desires no 〈◊〉 nor towns,
Nor to bear any office, rule or state,
Either by person or by substitute,
nor yet himself to be a counsellor in our affairs.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: What need he (Noble lords) to ask the
Fruit, when he demands the tree?
No castle, 〈◊〉, nor towers of strength,
It boots not, when the chiefest tower of all
The key that opens unto all the land.
I mean our gracious sovereign must be his,
But he will bear no office in the land,
And yet will marry with the Queen of all.
Nor be of counsel in the realm's affairs,
And yet the Queen enclosed in his arms:
I do not like this strange marriage
The fox is subtle, and his head once 〈◊〉
The slender body easily will follow.
I grant, he offers you in name of dowry,
The yearly sum of threescore thousand ducats.
Besides, the seventeen famous provinces,
And that the heir succeeding from your loins,
Shall have the sovereign rule of both the realms.
What, shall this move your highness to the match?
Spain is too far for England to inherit,
But England near enough for Spain to woe.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Has not the Kings of England (Good sir Thomas)
Espoused the daughters of our neighbour Kings?

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.l: I grant, your predecessors oft have sought
Their Queen from France,
And sometimes to from Spain.
But never could I hear that England yet
Has been so base, to seek a King from either:
'tis policy dear Queen, no love at all.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: 'Tis love great Queen, no policy at all.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: Which of you all, dares justify this match,
And not be touched in conscience with an oath?
Remember, oh remember I beseech you,
King Henry's last will, and his act at court,
I mean that royal court of parliament,
That does prohibit Spaniards from the land,
That will and act, to which you all are sworn,
And do not dam your souls with perjury.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: But that we know thee Wyatt to be true
Unto the crown of England and to us,
Thy overboldness should be paid with death.
But cease, for fear your liberal tongue offend,
With one consent my lords you like this match?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We do great sovereign.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Call in count Edmond honourable lords.
sp.l: We have determined of your embassy,
And thus I plight, our love to Philip's heart,
Embark you straight, the wind blows wondrous fair:
Till he shall land in England, I am all care.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.l: And ere he land in England, I will offer
My loyal breast for him to tread upon.
O who so forward Wyatt as thyself,
To raise this troublesome Queen in this her throne?
Philip is a Spaniard, a proud nation,
Whom naturally our country men abhor.
Assist me gracious heavens, and you shall see
What hate I bear unto their slavery.
I'll into Kent, there muster up my friends,
To save this country, and this realm defend.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Good morrow to the patron of my woe.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: God morrow to my lord, my lovely Dudley.
Why do you look so sad my dearest lord?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: Nay why doth Jane, thus with a heavy eye,
And a defected look, salute the day?
Sorrow doth ill become thy silver brow,
Sad grief lies dead, so long as thou lives fair,
In my Jane's joy, I do not care for care.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: My looks (My love) is sorted with my heart,
The sun himself, doth scantly show his face,
Out of this firm grate, you may perceive the tower-hill
Thronged with store of people,
As if they gaped for some strange novelty.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: Though sleep do seldom dwéll in men of care,
Yet I did this night sleep, and this night dreamt,
my princely father great (Northumberland)
Was married to a stately bride:
And then methought , just on his bridal day,
A poisoned draught did take his life away.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Let not fond visions so appall my love,
For dreams do oftentimes contrary prove.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: The nights are tedious, and the days are sad,
And see you how the people stand in heaps,
Each man sad, looking on his aposed object,
As if a general passion possessed them?
Their eyes do seem, as dropping as the moon,
As if prepared for a tragedy.
For never swarms of people there do tread,
But to rob life, and to i●ch the dead
And show they wept.

sp.speaker: Lef
sp.p: My lord they did so, for I was there.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I pray resolve us good master lieutenant
Who was it yonder, that rendered up his life
To nature's death?

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Pardon me my lord, 'tis felony to acquaint you with death of any prisoner, yet to resolve your grace, it was your father, great Northumberland, that this day lost his head.

sp.speaker: Guil
sp.l: Peace rest his soul, his sins be buried in his grave,
And not remembered in his epitaph: but who comes 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: My father prisoner!

sp.speaker: Suff:
sp.l: O Jane! now ●ght but fear thy title and thy state,
thou now must leave for a small grave.
Had I been contented to a been great, I had stood,
But now my rising, is pulled down with blood.
Farewell, point me my house of prayers.
Is grief so short? 'twas wont to be full of words,
'Tis true, but now death's lesson, bids a could adieu.
Farewell, thus friends on desperate journey's part,
Breaking of words with tears, that swells the heart.

sp.speaker: Lief:
sp.l: It is the pleasure of the Queen that you part lodgings.
Till your arraignment, which must be tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Jane:
sp.p: Good master lieutenant let us pray together.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Pardon me madam I may not, they that owe you, sway me.

sp.speaker: Guil:
sp.l: Entreat not Jane, though she our bodies part,
Our souls shall meet. Farewell my love.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: My Dudley, my own heart. Exit o●.

sp.speaker: Wyatt:
sp.l: Hold drum, stand gentlemen,
Give the word along: stand, stand:
Masters, friends, soldiers, and therefore gentlemen,
I know some of you wear warm purses
Lined with gold, to them I speak not,
But to such lean knaves that cannot put up
Crosses, thus I say, fight valiantly,
And by the marry God, you that have all
your life time silver lacked,
Shall now get crowns, marry they must be cracked.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: No matter, we'll change them for white money.

sp.speaker: Wiat:
sp.l: But it must needs be so, dear countrymen,
For soldiers are the masters of wars mint,
Blows are the stamps, they set upon with bullets,
And broken pates are when the brains lies spilt:
These light crowns, that with blood are double guilt,
But that's not all, that your stout hearts shall earn,
Stick to this glorious quarrel, and your names
Shall stand in chronicles ranked 〈◊〉 with Kings
You f●e your country from base Spanish thrall,
From ignominious slavery,
Who can digest a Spaniard, that's a true Englishman?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Would he might choke that digest him.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: He that loves freedom and his country,
Cry a Wyatt: he that will not, with my heart
Let him stand forth, shake hands,
And we'll depart.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: A Wyatt, a Wyatt, a Wyatt.

sp.speaker: Har:
sp.l: Forbear, or with the breath thy trumpet spends,
This shall let forth thy soul.

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: I am a herald, and challenge safety
By the law of arms.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: So shalt thou when thou art lawfully employed

sp.speaker: Wia:
sp.p: What loud knaves that?

sp.speaker: Nor:
sp.l: No knave sir Thomas, I am a true man
To my Queen, to whom thou art a traitor.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Knock him down.

sp.speaker: Wiat.
sp.l: Knock him down, fie no,
We'll handle him, he shall sound before he go.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: He comes from Norfolk and those fawning lords, in Mary's name, weighing out life to them that will with baseness bury it
Cease on him as a pernicious enemy.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.l: Sir George be ruled,
Since we profess the art of war,
Let's not be hissed at for our ignorance,
He shall pass and repass, juggle the best he can,
Lead him into the Crai●. Norry set forth
Set forth thy brazen throat and call all Rochester
About thee: do thy office, fill their
Light heads with proclamations, do,
Catch fools with lime-twigs dipped with pardons.
But sir George and good sir Harry Isley,
If this gallant open his mouth too wide,
Powder the varlet, pistol him, fire the roof that's o'er his mouth
He craves the law of arms, and he shall have't,
Teach him our law, to cut's throat if he prate.
If louder reach thy proclamation,
The lord have mercy upon thee.

sp.speaker: Nor
sp.p: Sir Thomas, I must do my office.

sp.speaker: Har:
sp.p: Come. We'll do ours too,

sp.speaker: Vvia.
sp.l: Ay, ay, do, blow thyself henceExit. Harper Isoly, and Norry.
Whoreson proved herald, because he can
Give arms, he thinks to cut us off by the elbows.
Masters and fellow soldiers, say, will you leave old
Tom Wyatt?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Wia.
sp.l: A march! 〈◊〉 Norfolk's drum upon my life.
I pray see what drum it is.
The word is given, arm, arm flies through the camp
As loud, though not so full of dread 〈◊〉 thunder:
For no man's 〈◊〉 look pale, but every face,
Is lifted up above his foremans head,
And every soldier does on 〈◊〉 stand,
Shaking a drawn sword in his threatening hand.

sp.speaker: Wiat:
sp.p: At whom, at whose drum?

sp.speaker: Rod:
sp.l: At Norfolk, Norfolk's drum:
With him comes Arundel, you may behold
The silken faces of their 〈◊〉 show,
Nothing but 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 in the wind,
Norfolk rides 〈◊〉, his crest well known,
Proud, as if all our heads were now his own.

sp.speaker: Wiat:
sp.l: Soft, he shall pay more for them.
Sir Robert Rodston, bring our 〈◊〉,
To 〈◊〉 our 〈◊〉, let all our archery,
Fall off in 〈◊〉 of shot a both sides of the van,
To gall the first horse of the enemy
That shall come fiercely on:
Our 〈◊〉, bid them to charge, charge my 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Wyatt:
sp.l: Saint George for England, Wyatt for poor Kent,
Blood lost in country's quarrel, is nobly spent.

sp.speaker: Isely:
sp.l: Base 〈◊〉, hard hearted fugitue,
He that you sent with Norry, false sir George
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 to Norfolk.

sp.speaker: Rod:
sp.p: Sir George Harper fled?

sp.l: 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 thought better of a counter ●ite,
His name was harper, was it not? 〈◊〉 him go,
Hence 〈◊〉 all 〈◊〉 for his sake shall stand,
But for plain nine pence, throughout all the land.
They come, no man give ground in these hot ca●es,
Be Englishmen and 〈◊〉 them to their faces. exeunt

And tender him soft mercy,

Therefore put in act, your resolute intendments,
If rebellion be suffered to take head,
She lives too long, treason doth swarm.
Therefore give signal to the fight,

You shall charge the traitor in the vanguard
Whilst myself with noble Arundel
And stout Jarningam, second you in the main,
God and saint George, this day fight on our side.
While thus we tame a desperate rebel's pride.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: But I am armed to die.

sp.speaker: Guilf:
sp.l: Likelier to live:
Death to the unwilling doth his presence give?
He dares not look the bold man in the face,
But on the fearful lays his killing mace.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: It is the pleasure of the Queen, that the
Lady Jane must first suffer death.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I thank her highness,
That I shall first depart this hapless world,
〈◊〉 not survive to see my dear love dead.

sp.speaker: Guilfo:
sp.p: She dying first, I three times lose my head.

sp.speaker: Head●.
sp.p: Forgive me lady I pray your death.

sp.speaker: Guilf:
sp.p: Ha? hast thou the heart to kill a face so fair.
It is her headsman.

sp.speaker: Guil:
sp.l: And demands a pardon,
Only of her, for taking off her head?

sp.p: I gentle Guilford, and I pardon him.

sp.speaker: Guil:
sp.l: But I'll not pardon him, thou art my wife.
And he shall ask me pardon for thy life,

sp.p: Pardon 〈◊〉 lord.

sp.speaker: Gui:
sp.l: Rise, do not kneel.
Though thou submit'st, thou hast a lowering steel
Whose fatal declination brings our death:
good man of earth, make haste to make us ear●.

sp.speaker: Heds.
sp.p: Pleaseth the lady Jane, I'll help her off with her nightgown.

Off with these robes, oh 〈◊〉 the● from my side,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Madam almost.

sp.speaker: Jane:
sp.l: Not yet, oh God! how hardly can we
Shake off this world's pomp,
That cleaves unto us like our body's 〈◊〉
Yet thus oh God shake of thy servant's sin.

sp.speaker: Win:
sp.p: Hear comes the headsman, with the head of Jane:
Who spoke of Jane? who named my lovely Jane?
Behold her head.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: O I shall faint again!
Yet let me bear this fight unto my 〈◊〉
My sweet Jane's head:
Look Norfolk, Arundel, Winchester

Thus when they die 〈◊〉 ruddy lip,

sp.p: My lord, the time run on.

sp.l: So does our death.
Here's one has run so fast she's out of breath,
But the time goes on,
And 〈◊〉 fair Jane's white soul, will be
In heaven before me
If I do stay: stay gentle wife,
Thy Guilford follows thee,
Though on the earth we part, by adverse fate,

My lords farewell, 〈◊〉 farewell to all,
The father's pride has caused the children's fall.
Thus have we seen her highness' will performed,
And now their heads and bodies shall be joined
And buried in one grave, as fits their loves.
Thus much I'll say in their behalfs now dead,

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
